boxed-text.title: Grants and Awards
boxed-text.p: The National Science Teachers Association (NSTA) offers a variety of awards to educators:

list-item.p: The Angela Award honors one female student in Grades 5 to 8 who is involved in or has a strong connection to science, provides evidence of sustained accomplishments or progress/interest in science, and has quality support material. Eligible applicants are any female students in Grades 5 to 8. Maximum award is $1,000 U.S. EE Savings Bond or Canadian Savings Bond. The awardee will also be honored at the Teacher Awards Banquet at NSTA’s National Conference. Deadline is November 30.

Delta Education/Fre-Neo/CPO Science Education Awards for Excellence in Inquiry-Based Science Teaching recognizes and honors three full-time PreK-12 teachers of science who successfully use inquiry-based science to enhance teaching and learning in their classroom. Eligible applicants are any PreK-12 teachers. Maximum award is US$1,500 toward expenses to attend the NSTA national Conference, and US$1,500 for the awardees. Deadline is November 30.

SeaWorld Parks and Entertainment Outstanding Environmental Educator of the Year recognizes and rewards an outstanding teacher who is working at the grassroots level to protect and preserve the environment. Eligible applicants are public and private schools, youth, adults, and environmental educators. Maximum award is US$10,000, an expenses-paid trip for themselves and one guest to a SeaWorld or Busch Gardens part for a special awards event, and an all-expenses-paid trip to the NSTA National Conference on Science Education. Deadline to receive nominations for this year’s award is December 31.

Shell Science Teaching Award recognizes one outstanding classroom science teacher who has had a positive impact on his or her students, school, and community through exemplary classroom science teaching. Eligible applicants are K-12 classroom science teachers that have a minimum of 8 years of experience. Applicants will submit a video of no longer than 30 min that features classroom activities with students that clearly reflect the candidate’s teaching philosophy and application submission. The committee will then form a subcommittee of three members who will visit each finalist. Site visits take place at the candidates’ schools in February. Maximum award is US$10,000 and an all-expense paid trip to attend NSTA’s National Conference; two finalists will also receive all-expense-paid trips to the conference. Deadline is November 12.

Sylvia Shugrue Award for Elementary Teachers honors one elementary school teacher who has established an interdisciplinary, inquiry-based lesson plan. Eligible applicants are elementary school teachers (Grades K-6) who have a minimum of 5 years of experience. Maximum award consists of US$1,000 and up to US$500 to attend the NSTA National Conference on Science Education. Deadline is November 30.

boxed-text.p: For more information about all of these awards, visit http://www.nsta.org/about/awards.aspx?lid=tnavhp#shell

The International Reading Association/Weekly Reader Eleanor M. Johnson Award recognizes an outstanding elementary classroom teacher of reading/language arts. Criteria include knowledge of reading/language arts, teaching effectiveness, willingness to share ideas and methods, impact on colleagues, and demonstrated enthusiasm for reading/language arts. Eligible applicants are elementary classroom teachers of reading/language arts who work directly with students on a consistent basis. Maximum award is US$1,000. Deadline is November 15. For more information, visit http://www.reading.org/Resources/AwardsandGrants/teachers_johnson.aspx

The College Board Bob Costas Awards for the Teaching of Creative Writing support exceptional teachers who through their innovative teaching methods motivate their students to write. Winning teachers are awarded grants to enhance successful projects currently underway. Projects can be carried out in school (public or nonpublic), through an after-school writing workshop, or during a summer program. Eligible applicants are teachers from all academic disciplines Grades 6 to 12. Maximum award is US$3,000. Deadline is November 21. For more information, visit http://professionals.collegeboard.com/k-12/awards/costas

The College Board Inspiration Awards celebrate high schools that have improved their academic environment and helped their students achieve the promise of a higher education by initiating unique programs and creating partnerships among teachers, parents, community organizations, and local businesses. Eligibility applicants are secondary schools (public and nonpublic) in which 40% or more of the students receive free- or reduced-price lunches. Maximum award is US$25,000. Deadline is November 30. For more information, visit http://professionals.collegeboard.com/k-12/awards/inspiration

In partnership with the Duke Energy Foundation, the Foundation for Appalachian Ohio offers ICAN! Classroom Enrichment Mini-Grants to support the efforts of teachers in connecting their classrooms with Science, Technology, Engineering, Mathematics, or Medicine (STEMM) related businesses and professions. The purpose of the grants is to assist educators in increasing students’ interest in careers associated with STEMM through in-house or on-site field trips to an area business. Educators and their students will be required to capture the STEMM business visit on camera, through tours and interviews. To assist with this requirement, each grant will include funds to purchase an iPad and a US$25 iTunes Card in addition to any other needed supplies. Eligible applicants are K-12 teachers and/or guidance counselors throughout the 32-county region of Appalachian Ohio. In addition, applicants are required to have an account on the Southeast Ohio STEMM Virtual Hub. Maximum award is US$1,225. Deadlines occur annually in September. For additional information, visit http://www.appalachianohio.org/grantees/index.php?section=260&page=482

The National Association for Gifted Children (NAGC) also makes awards in a variety of categories. Applications for all of these awards are due May 1, 2013. Visit the NAGC website for more information regarding the application process: http://www.nagc.org/awards.aspx

list-item.p: The Hollingworth Award encourages educational and psychological research studies of potential benefit to gifted and talented children. Eligible applicants include individuals, educational institutions, and other organizations that present proposals for publishable research projects concerning gifted and talented individuals. Maximum award consists of a cash grant, paid in two installments: first at the awards ceremony and after receipt of the final report.

The A. Harry Passow Classroom Teacher Scholarship to teachers of Grades K-12 who have shown excellence in teaching gifted students, the ability to meet the need of gifted students, and commitment to furthering the development of their teaching skills. Eligible applicants include teachers in Grades K-12 who currently teach gifted students ranging from a homogeneous or full-day special class to a heterogeneous classroom. The maximum award is a plaque and a check to reimburse/defray the costs of continuing education.

The NAGC/Ball State Administrator Award is presented to a school administrator outside the field of gifted education who has made the most significant contribution to gifted education in his or her school district. The contribution may include developing and maintaining a school wide or district wide gifted education program; offering high level of support for gifted students, or public advocacy for the needs of gifted children. Eligible applicants include principals or superintendents outside the field of gifted education who currently serve in the position. The maximum award includes a plaque, a check, and a complimentary registration at the NAGC Annual Convention.

The David W. Belin Advocacy Award is presented to an individual or group that has successfully advocated at the state or federal level to incorporate gifted education in a significant and meaningful way into state or federal policy. Eligible applicants may be individuals, public officials, or groups whose commitment to gifted and talented children is evidenced by his or her work to develop or strengthen gifted education policy at the state or federal level. The maximum award includes a plaque and a monetary contribution made by NAGC in the recipient’s honor to a gifted and talented organization of their choice.

The Community Service Award is presented to an individual or group that has made a significant contribution to education, science, the arts, humanities, parenting and the family, public policy, or another field that affects the larger community, state, or nation. Eligible applicants are any individual or group that has made a contribution. The maximum award is a plaque presented at the NAGC Annual Convention.

The Early Leader Award is given to an individual who has exhibited the highest and most consistent degree of leadership in local, state, and national organizations for the gifted that resulted in a unique contribution. Eligible applicants are individuals in the first 10 years of their career after completing his or her last earned degree. The maximum award is a 1-year membership to NAGC, a featured speaker’s position at the Annual Convention, and a plaque.

The Early Scholar Award is given to an individual who has made significant contributions in conducting and reporting research regarding the education of gifted and talented individuals. Eligible applicants are individuals in the first 10 years of their career after completing his or her last earned degree. The maximum award is a 1-year membership to NAGC, a featured speaker’s position at the Annual Convention, and a plaque.

sec.title: Scholarship Trust for the Hearing Impaired
sec.p: The Traveling Men’s Club was formed in January 1882 when a group of traveling men discussed the problems that confronted salesmen and the need for cooperation in solving them. Today, the National Headquarters in St. Louis, Missouri, exists to promote fraternalism for members and friends, safety projects and community service, and accident, death, and disability benefits for members and their beneficiaries. The Travelers Protective Association (TPA) Scholarship Trust for the Hearing Impaired was established in 1975 to provide financial aid to children and adults who suffer deafness or hearing impairment. To date, the Trust has distributed US$1,773,295.00 to 4,170 recipients. In April, trustees will review all applications. Applicants who demonstrate the greatest financial need are given preference in the selection process regardless of race, creed, age, or sex. The number of scholarships and the amount of the scholarship awards will be decided on by the majority of the trustees. Recipients will be notified in May, and scholarship checks will be mailed after September 1. Former scholarship recipients may reapply in subsequent years for additional aid. Applications are due by March 1 of each year. For more information, please visit http://www.tpahq.org/index.html.

sec.title: Communication Arts Photography Competition
sec.p: Founded in 1959, Communication Arts exists to promote the highest professional standards for those in visual communication such as graphic designers, art directors, design firms, corporate design departments, advertising agencies, interactive designers, illustrators, and photographers. The Communication Arts Photography Competition was created to promote creativity in photography. Applicants are welcome to submit any photograph first printed or produced from March 2012 through March 2013. A nationally representative jury of distinguished designers, art directors, and photographers will judge the photographs, and the winning entries will be distributed worldwide in the Communication Arts Photography Annual and on http://www.commarts.com. The submission categories include the following: Advertising, Books (cover/jacket and/or interior), Editorial, For Sale, Institutional, Multimedia, Self-Promotion, and Unpublished (commissioned but not published, personal or student work, etc.). A single photograph can be submitted or a series of no more than five photographs may be submitted. Entries must be registered by March 15, 2013. Entries registered after this date require a late fee of US$10 per entry. No entries will be accepted after March 29, 2013. For more information, please visit http://www.commarts.com/competitions/photography

sec.title: National Economics Challenge
sec.p: The Council for Economic Education (CEE) focuses on the economic and financial education of kindergarten through high school students. The goal of the CEE has been to foster a real-world understanding of economics and personal finance for the past 60 years. This foundation of economic and financial literacy will enable today’s students to grow into successful and productive adults capable of making informed and responsible decisions in the future. To carry out its mission, the CEE provides professional development to teachers, teaching resources across the curriculum and nationally normed assessment tools through in-person local workshops, partner organizations, and online delivery of materials. In addition, the CEE partners with State Farm® to host an annual National Economics Challenge that encourages students to apply their economics knowledge and work in teams. Student teams will answer questions on microeconomics, macroeconomics, international economics, and current events. Competitions are held at the state, national semi-final, and national levels. At the national level, students complete rounds of testing, work in teams to solve case problems, and participate in a quick-paced oral quiz-bowl to compete for the title of National Champions. To participate in their state’s competition, students should contact their local coordinator. State coordinators will need to submit teacher and student registration forms to CEE for the champions in each division that advance to the National Semi-Finals. The 2013 National Economics Challenge will take place in New York City from May 17 to 20, 2013. For more information, please visit http://www.councilforeconed.org/events/national-economics-challenge/.

sec.title: BMEidea 2013 Competition
sec.p: The National Collegiate Inventors and Innovators Alliance (NCIIA) organizes two biomedical engineering competitions for university students each year. The purpose of these competitions is to identify and recognize innovative medical devices and technologies developed by entrepreneurial student teams that can be manufactured for commercial use.

One of these competitions is BMEidea, the United States’ leading competition for biomedical and bioengineering students (sponsored by the NCIIA; Boston Scientific; MD&DI [Medical Device & Diagnostic Industry], a publication of Canon Communications LLC; and Industrial Designers Society of America [IDSA], in partnership with the Biomedical Engineering Society [BMES] and the Council of Chairs of Bioengineering and Biomedical Engineering Programs). Undergraduate and graduate students are welcome to apply. Applicants should define a problem and demonstrate how a health-related technology that students invented addresses a real-life clinical need. Examples include but are not limited to surgical devices; home health care devices; diagnostic, therapeutic, and preventative applications; rehabilitative and assistive technologies; or other innovations that will have a substantial impact on clinical care and patient outcomes. Entries will be judged on the following categories: (a) technical, economic, and regulatory feasibility; (b) contribution to human health and quality of life; (c) technological innovation; (d) potential for commercialization; and (e) general information. The categories for product designs may include the following: (a) surgery, (b) therapeutic applications, (c) diagnostic applications, (d) rehabilitative and assistive technologies, and (e) home health care. The alliance encourages multidisciplinary teams and interinstitutional teams to apply, as long as there is a faculty advisor from each institution. Each team must contain at least one engineering student. The first place team will receive US$10,000, second place will receive US$2,500, and the third place team will receive US$1,000. The team members will have rights to all intellectual property, in accordance with the rules of their institutions. BMEidea applications are due on April 5, 2013. Judging will take place on April 6 through May 17. Finalists will be notified after judging, and awards will be presented to winners at the 2013 MD&M Medical Device Tradeshow and Convention in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. For application details and more information, please visit http://nciia.org/competitions/.
